title: Chinese Government provides RMB 25 million grant for provision of mobile scanning devices to combat drug and arms trafficking
description: On February 5, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed letters of exchange for on a grant of RMB 25 million (3.7 million USD) for the provision of mobile x-ray (customs inspection) equipment to prevent smuggling and boost trade. The RMB 25 million grant was drawn from the proceeds of an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that was signed on August 23, 2006. The grant agreement was finalized and signed by both parties on April 2, 2009. The purpose of the grant was to equip customs posts (border checkpoints) with mobile scanning equipment to combat smuggling, drug trafficking, and arms trafficking. No additional implementation details are available.
staff_comments: 1. The Russian project title is приобретение передвижных сканирующих комплексов для узбекских пограничных пунктов.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 25 million grant for provision of mobile scanning devices to combat drug and arms trafficking

# Description
On February 5, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed letters of exchange for on a grant of RMB 25 million (3.7 million USD) for the provision of mobile x-ray (customs inspection) equipment to prevent smuggling and boost trade. The RMB 25 million grant was drawn from the proceeds of an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that was signed on August 23, 2006. The grant agreement was finalized and signed by both parties on April 2, 2009. The purpose of the grant was to equip customs posts (border checkpoints) with mobile scanning equipment to combat smuggling, drug trafficking, and arms trafficking. No additional implementation details are available.
justification: Project focuses on customs enforcement and trade security without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of mobile x-ray equipment for customs inspection, focus on combating smuggling and trafficking

title: China Eximbank provides $70.11 million preferential buyer's credit loan for the purchase of Chinese electric locomotives (Linked to Project ID#40131)
description: In November 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) in which China pledged to offer concessional loans to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of electric locomotives from China.  In May 2009, Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC) signed a contract with CSR Zhuzhou Electric Locomotive Company for the supply of 15 electric locomotives. The total cost of the project was $75.53 million. The Export-Import Bank of China provided a $70,110,000 preferential buyer's credit loan to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan to support this contract. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate of 2%, a commitment fee of 0.3%, and a management fee of 0.3%. Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC covered the remaining cost of the project.  The projected speed of the electric locomotives was 160 km per hour, which would allow to double passenger turnover at the electrified railway roads of Uzbekistan. The new locomotives were to be used on the Samarkand-Khojidavlet railway line and Navoi-Samarkand line.  All 15 electric locomotives were delivered to Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC by the end of 2010.
staff_comments: 1. The Russian name of this project is «Узбекистон темир йуллари». Закупки пассажирских электровозов».
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

# Description
In November 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) in which China pledged to offer concessional loans to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of electric locomotives from China.  In May 2009, Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC) signed a contract with CSR Zhuzhou Electric Locomotive Company for the supply of 15 electric locomotives. The total cost of the project was $75.53 million. The Export-Import Bank of China provided a $70,110,000 preferential buyer's credit loan to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan to support this contract. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate of 2%, a commitment fee of 0.3%, and a management fee of 0.3%. Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC covered the remaining cost of the project.  The projected speed of the electric locomotives was 160 km per hour, which would allow to double passenger turnover at the electrified railway roads of Uzbekistan. The new locomotives were to be used on the Samarkand-Khojidavlet railway line and Navoi-Samarkand line.  All 15 electric locomotives were delivered to Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC by the end of 2010.
justification: Electric locomotives contribute to reducing emissions compared to diesel locomotives, supporting cleaner transportation infrastructure
evidence: Purchase of 15 electric locomotives for railway system, projected to double passenger turnover on electrified lines

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant — via ETCA — for Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project
description: In 2009, Chinese Government provided a RMB 50 million interest-free loan for Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. On June 27, 2009, the Chinese Government committed RMB 60 million to the Government of Uzbekistan through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA). Using RMB 50 million of the proceeds from this ETCA, the Government of Uzbekistan obtained an interest-free loan for the Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. To support this loan agreement, an inter-bank agreement was signed between China Development Bank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan on May 28, 2010.   The Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project sought to reconstruct a Karakul district pumping station in Bukhara region (oblast). It did so by, among other things, facilitating the acquisition of pump equipment. China IPPR International Engineering Corporation was the contractor. This pump station is responsible for the irrigation of nearly 30,000 hectares of land in the Karakul region and the water supply for 769 livestock farms. During the slack season, the pump station is used to wash saline-alkali soil. The primary and auxiliary Karakul pump stations have been operating for over 40 years and 25 years, respectively, and long exceeded the normal service life of mechanical and electrical equipment. The poorly serviced equipment were no longer able to satisfy the local irrigation needs. The successful completion and operation of the Karakul Pump Station Reconstruction Project on schedule further expanded the irrigation coverage of the pump station, not only restoring and improving the agricultural irrigation and drainage conditions, but also effectively improving the salinealkali soil environment. The Karakul region, one of the most important cotton production areas of Uzbekistan, had an excellent harvest of cotton in that very year. In 2012, both the region’s irrigated cotton plantation area and output ranked second across the country and the cotton festival, which had been abandoned for over a decade, was revived, attracting over 200,000 visitors.    According to legislation from the Republic of Uzbekistan, the implementation of the project started in 2011. This project was initiated in 2006 and completed on January 13, 2013.
staff_comments: 1. The Russian project title is 'Реконструкция насосной станции 'Каракуль' в Бухарской области”.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant — via ETCA — for Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project

# Description
In 2009, Chinese Government provided a RMB 50 million interest-free loan for Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. On June 27, 2009, the Chinese Government committed RMB 60 million to the Government of Uzbekistan through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA). Using RMB 50 million of the proceeds from this ETCA, the Government of Uzbekistan obtained an interest-free loan for the Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. To support this loan agreement, an inter-bank agreement was signed between China Development Bank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan on May 28, 2010.   The Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project sought to reconstruct a Karakul district pumping station in Bukhara region (oblast). It did so by, among other things, facilitating the acquisition of pump equipment. China IPPR International Engineering Corporation was the contractor. This pump station is responsible for the irrigation of nearly 30,000 hectares of land in the Karakul region and the water supply for 769 livestock farms. During the slack season, the pump station is used to wash saline-alkali soil. The primary and auxiliary Karakul pump stations have been operating for over 40 years and 25 years, respectively, and long exceeded the normal service life of mechanical and electrical equipment. The poorly serviced equipment were no longer able to satisfy the local irrigation needs. The successful completion and operation of the Karakul Pump Station Reconstruction Project on schedule further expanded the irrigation coverage of the pump station, not only restoring and improving the agricultural irrigation and drainage conditions, but also effectively improving the salinealkali soil environment. The Karakul region, one of the most important cotton production areas of Uzbekistan, had an excellent harvest of cotton in that very year. In 2012, both the region’s irrigated cotton plantation area and output ranked second across the country and the cotton festival, which had been abandoned for over a decade, was revived, attracting over 200,000 visitors.    According to legislation from the Republic of Uzbekistan, the implementation of the project started in 2011. This project was initiated in 2006 and completed on January 13, 2013.
justification: Project focuses on irrigation infrastructure and agricultural support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Pumping station reconstruction for irrigation and water supply, agricultural benefits, no direct energy transition components

title: China Eximbank provides $26.3 million loan for 220kv and 110kv Tashkent External Power Supply Facilities Project
description: In 2009, China Eximbank loaned $26,354,900 USD to Uzbekistan for the 220kv and 110kv Tashkent External Power Supply Facilities Project. This loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.3% commitment fee, 0.3% management fee.  The project involved the construction of a 220 kV transmitting station “Keles” with high-voltage line of 220 kV, a “Navoi” transmission substation of 110 kV, and a “Sayilgoh” transmission station of 110 kV with cable line of 110 kV. It entered implementation on September 4, 2009. The project is planned to reach completion in 2012.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 建设塔什干外部供电设施.
combined_text:
# Sector

This loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.3% commitment fee, 0.3% management fee.  The project involved the construction of a 220 kV transmitting station “Keles” with high-voltage line of 220 kV, a “Navoi” transmission substation of 110 kV, and a “Sayilgoh” transmission station of 110 kV with cable line of 110 kV. title: China Eximbank provide $10.7 million loan for ICT in Rural Areas Project
description: In 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $10,722,880 loan agreement withthe  National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan for an ICT in Rural Areas Project. The terms of the loan were as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period. 2.5% interest, 0.3% management fee, and 0.3% commitment fee. The proceeds of the loan were used to support contracts between Uzbektelecom JSC and Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd and ZTE Corporation.
staff_comments: 1. The Russian name of this project is 'Развитие информационно-коммуникационной структуры АК 'Узбектелеком' в сельской местности'.2. Source ID#161206 suggests this loan was actually two separate loans, worth $6.4 million and $4.4 million, issued by China Eximbank. This issue merits further investigation.

title: Chinese Government provides $2.9 million grant — via ETCA — for USP Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#63179)
description: On June 29, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Vanuatu signed letters of exchange, which committed grant funding for a feasibility study of the USP Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) Expansion Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly committed $2.9 million of total grant funding for this project. The grant proceeds were drawn (at least in part) from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed in 2009 (see Project ID#63179).   The purpose of the project was to expand the Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) at the University of the South Pacific (USP) in Port Vila on Efate Island. It involved the construction of classrooms, a computer and language lab, offices, a library, laboratories, and a gymnasium. The campus was also outfitted with computers, laboratory instruments, desks, chairs, and fitness equipment.   Dalian Zhucheng Construction Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for implementation. It signed and construction contract in September 2011. Then, a formal foundation stone-laying ceremony took place on December 7, 2011,. Construction commenced on April 15, 2012 and was completed on October 25, 2013. A formal project handover ceremony took place on October 28, 2013 and the expanded campus was officially opened on December 4, 2013, the Francophone Wing was officially opened.
staff_comments: The exact grant commitment year uncertain. For the time being, it is coded as 2009 since this is the year in which the ETCA was signed.The Chinese project title is 中国援助瓦努阿图南太大学埃马路斯分校扩建项目 or 瓦努阿图南太大学埃马路斯分校扩建项目 or 大洋洲瓦努阿图项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2.9 million grant — via ETCA — for USP Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#63179)

# Description
On June 29, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Vanuatu signed letters of exchange, which committed grant funding for a feasibility study of the USP Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) Expansion Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly committed $2.9 million of total grant funding for this project. The grant proceeds were drawn (at least in part) from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed in 2009 (see Project ID#63179).   The purpose of the project was to expand the Emalus Campus (Francophone Wing) at the University of the South Pacific (USP) in Port Vila on Efate Island. It involved the construction of classrooms, a computer and language lab, offices, a library, laboratories, and a gymnasium. The campus was also outfitted with computers, laboratory instruments, desks, chairs, and fitness equipment.   Dalian Zhucheng Construction Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for implementation. It signed and construction contract in September 2011. Then, a formal foundation stone-laying ceremony took place on December 7, 2011,. Construction commenced on April 15, 2012 and was completed on October 25, 2013. A formal project handover ceremony took place on October 28, 2013 and the expanded campus was officially opened on December 4, 2013, the Francophone Wing was officially opened.
justification: Project focuses on educational infrastructure expansion without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of classrooms, labs, library, and gymnasium for university campus expansion

title: Chinese Embassy donates books and other materials to Port Vila Public Library
description: On May 8, 2009, Wu Baofeng, the wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Vanuatu, on behalf of the Chinese Embassy in Vanuatu, donated materials such as books and pamphlets about China, as well as a TV set and DVD player to the Port Vila Public Library. The books were intended to to provide readers with the history, culture, customs, and geography of China as well as details regarding its tourism sector and the people’s daily life. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.

title: China grants Vanuatu 167 million Vatu to encourage university enrollment
description: In January 2009, Prime Minister Natapei and China’s Vice Minister of Commerce, Vu Su Chung signed an agreement under which China would provide VT167 million to the Vanuatu government. The grant would be used to extend enrollment at the University of the South Pacific (USP) Emalus Campus in Port Vila  to Francophone students.

title: China Sent 7th Table Tennis Coach to Vanuatu in 2009
description: On February 17, 2009, letters of exchange were signed between Ambassador Cheng Shuping and Vanuatu Foreign Minister Bakker Kartongga for a two-year-long Table Tennis Coaching project to Vaula (or 第七期乒乓球教练项目). This is the seventh table tennis coaching project and the sixth project has been captured in project #62863. Another coach was sent in 2013 and is recorded in #39249.
staff_comments: This project is assumed to be complete. The exact start and end dates are unclear.

title: Chinese Government provides Human Resources Training for Vanuatu Government Officials in China
description: On October 15th, 2009, 30 Vanuatu Government Officials started Human Resources training in China (or 援外人力资源培训项目). The training included 15 classes which, according to the press release from the Chinese Government ("我援外人力资源培训项目受到瓦努阿图政府的欢迎和好评") cover "inspection and quarantine [of foreign aid], tourism management, sports, health, trade and investment, and new energy." The course lasted from October 15 to November 4, 2009.  Since 2005, more than 200 government officials and technical experts in Vanuatu have participated in China's foreign aid training programs. These training courses or seminars usually last 2-3 weeks and are generally held in Beijing, Shanghai or provincial capitals. The theme is set according to the specific requirements of Vanuatu, covering many areas such as macroeconomic development, investment promotion, public management, climate change, food safety, disaster early warning and rescue management, medical and health, and agricultural product production and processing. Human resources training is an important part of the Chinese government's assistance to Vanuatu.
combined_text:

These training courses or seminars usually last 2-3 weeks and are generally held in Beijing, Shanghai or provincial capitals. The theme is set according to the specific requirements of Vanuatu, covering many areas such as macroeconomic development, investment promotion, public management, climate change, food safety, disaster early warning and rescue management, medical and health, and agricultural product production and processing. evidence: Training topics include inspection and quarantine, tourism management, sports, health, trade and investment, with only minor mention of new energy among many other topics
